Sadece database seviyesinde bir problem varsa, a≈üaƒüƒ±daki adƒ±mlar ile sorunlu database en son backuptan restore edilebilir.

1. Sorunlu database silinir.¬†Warning: Silerken "Delete backup and restore history information for database" kutucuƒüu bo≈ü bƒ±rakƒ±lƒ±r
2. Diskteki database dosyalarƒ±nƒ±n da silindiƒüinden emin olunur.
3. A≈üaƒüƒ±daki scriptte¬†@SourceDb ve @DrivePath deƒüi≈ükenleri restore edilmek istenen database adƒ±yla ve databasein bulunacaƒüƒ± drive adƒ±yla deƒüi≈ütirilir ve √ßalƒ±≈ütƒ±rƒ±lƒ±r.

```sql
Use Tools

Exec sp_AwesomeRecovery @SourceDb = 'Toypa', @DrivePath = 'K';
```

Server seviyesinde bir fail durumunda, problemli serverƒ±n sistem diski haftalƒ±k alƒ±nan snapshottan recover edilebilir.

- Bu i≈ülem Windows ve Linux serverlar i√ßin aynƒ± ≈üekilde uygulanmaktadƒ±r.¬†√ñrnek olarak Linux bir server se√ßilmi≈ütir.
- Aws ortamƒ±nda disk ekleme √ßƒ±karma konusunda fikir sahibi olmak i√ßin confluencetaki ≈üu sayfa incelenebilir.
- Bu adƒ±mlar Amazon tarafƒ±ndaki problemlerden dolayƒ± servera eri≈üilememesi durumunda serverƒ± kurtarmaz. B√∂ylesi bir durumda a≈üaƒüƒ±daki 2.¬†adƒ±mda Create Volume yerine¬†Create Image se√ßeneƒüi se√ßilir ve kuruluma ≈üu sayfadaki¬†2. adƒ±mdaki My AMIs se√ßeneƒüi se√ßilerek devam edilir.

Recovery i√ßin a≈üaƒüƒ±daki adƒ±mlar sƒ±rasƒ±yla uygulanƒ±r.

ƒ∞≈ülemin Adƒ±mlarƒ±:1.Snapshottan Volume olu≈üturmak i√ßin¬†ilk √∂nce Amazonun EC2 servisine giriyoruz. Sol taraftaki Snapshots se√ßeneƒüini se√ßip sorunlu servera ait son snapshotƒ± buluyoruz.

ine giriyoruz. Sol taraftaki Snapshots se√ßeneƒüini se√ßip sorunlu servera ait son snapshotƒ± buluyoruz.

2.ƒ∞lgili snapshota tƒ±klayƒ±p Actions men√ºs√ºnden¬†Create Volumese√ßeneƒüine basƒ±yoruz. Gelen ekranda snapshopttan olu≈üturulacak diskin boyutunu belirliyoruz. Availability Zone se√ßeneƒüini serverƒ±n bulunduƒüu zone a g√∂re se√ßip Create butonuna basƒ±yoruz.

> Info: Boyut belirlerken √∂nceki sistem diski ile aynƒ± boyutu se√ßmek zorunda deƒüiliz, ihtiya√ß varsa daha b√ºy√ºk boyutlu disk ekleyebiliriz.

3.Volumes men√ºs√ºnde yaratƒ±lan diskin olu≈üturulmasƒ±nƒ± bekliyoruz. Bekleme sƒ±rasƒ±nda disk i√ßin gereken tagleme i≈ülemi yapƒ±labilir.¬†State kƒ±smƒ± available olduƒüunda diskin olu≈üturulma i≈ülemi tamamlanmƒ±≈ütƒ±r.

4.ƒ∞lgili server kapalƒ± deƒüilse Instances men√ºs√ºnden ilgili server se√ßilerek Actions men√ºs√ºnden¬†Instance State > Stopse√ßeneƒüiyle server kapatƒ±lƒ±r.

5.Server kapandƒ±ktan sonra servera baƒülƒ± sistem diski se√ßilip¬†Action men√ºs√ºnden¬†Detach Volume¬†se√ßeneƒüi ile disk serverdan ayƒ±rƒ±lƒ±r.

era baƒülƒ± sistem diski se√ßilip¬†Action men√ºs√ºnden¬†Detach Volume¬†se√ßeneƒüi ile disk serverdan ayƒ±rƒ±lƒ±r.

6.Yeni olu≈üturduƒüumuz diski servera baƒülamak i√ßin diski se√ßip¬†Action men√ºs√ºnden¬†Attach Volume¬†se√ßeneƒüini se√ßiyoruz. ƒ∞lgili yerleri doldurup¬†Attachbutonuna basƒ±yoruz.

> Warning: Instance se√ßeneƒüinden ilgili serverƒ± se√ßtikten sonra Device kƒ±smƒ±na /dev/sda1¬†yazmamƒ±z gerekiyor. Sistem diskleri sadece bu ≈üekilde tanƒ±mlanƒ±yor.

7.ƒ∞≈ülem bittikten sonra serverƒ± 4. adƒ±mda g√∂sterilen men√ºden stop yerine¬†Start¬†ƒ± se√ßerek yeniden ba≈ülatƒ±yoruz.

> Info: Bu yeniden ba≈ülama ve serverƒ±n aktif olarak √ßalƒ±≈ümaya ba≈ülamasƒ± ~1 saat kadar s√ºrebiliyor.

Bu dok√ºmanda Disaster anƒ±nda internal s√ºre√ßlerden m√º≈üteriye sonu√ß ekranlarƒ±na denk t√ºm servislerin sƒ±fƒ±rdan kurgulanmasƒ± ele alƒ±nacaktƒ±r.

Her servisin √ßalƒ±≈üma amacƒ±, backup saklanmasƒ± ve disaster senaryolarƒ± i√ßin estimated recovery s√ºreleri belirtilecektir.

## Recover Delta Lake

Regardless of the cloud provider or data storage technology, you can recover Delta tables using SQL on Databricks.

> Note: Not all projects have Databricks. These need to be opened by admins if your project does not have one.

For each table that needs to be recovered, run the following SQL query in a Databricks notebook:

```sql
RESTORE TABLE delta.`/data/target/` TO TIMESTAMP AS OF <timestamp>
```

For example; if the project datastore is mounted into ‚Äú/mnt/datastore‚Äú in the Databricks workspace, and you want to rollback ‚Äúoperation/sales‚Äù table to 2021-01-01, run this:

```
RESTORE TABLE delta.`/mnt/datastore/operation/sales` TO TIMESTAMP AS OF 2021-01-01
```

Useful documents

ORE TABLE delta.`/mnt/datastore/operation/sales` TO TIMESTAMP AS OF 2021-01-01
```

Useful documents

- Azurehttps://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/sql/language-manual/delta-restore https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/databricks/delta/history#restore
- Amazonhttps://docs.databricks.com/sql/language-manual/delta-restore.html https://docs.databricks.com/delta/history.html#restore

## Recover Amazon S3

S3 does not have an official point-in-time recovery feature. There is a community project for that.

[https://github.com/angeloc/s3-pit-restore](https://github.com/angeloc/s3-pit-restore)This can be used for restoring S3.

1. Follow the installation guide in the s3-pit-restore project
2. Run the following in a command prompt such as Terminal, Bash, or PowerShell.s3-pit-restore -b <source-bucket-name> -B <dest-bucket-name> -p "<source-folder-prefix>" -P "<dest-folder-prefix>" -t "<time>"Parameter details:-b <source-bucket-name>: Customer datastore bucket-B <dest-bucket-name>: Usually same with <source-bucket-name>-p "<source-folder-prefix>": Optional. Name of the folder that to be restored.-P "<dest-folder-prefix>": Optional. Destination folder. It is a good practice to use this. Otherwise the program will override the actual files, meaning, if anything goes wrong, you cannot rollback. So, always use this option, check the recovered files and see that everything is ok, then move the recovered files to the right place.-t "<time>": The time that you want to time-travel. For example, "11-03-2022 09:00:00 +3". IMPORTANT: Date format is ‚ÄúMONTH- DAY-YEAR‚Äú. It is different the one that we used to. Be careful.

". IMPORTANT: Date format is ‚ÄúMONTH- DAY-YEAR‚Äú. It is different the one that we used to. Be careful.

> Note: Disclaimer: We observed inconsistencies within time-series tables when we used this program. We went over each table and fixed the issue. We might need to find a better program for this purpose.

## Recover Azure Blob

### Point-in-Time Recovery

Azure Blob supports ‚Äúpoint-in-time recovery‚Äù, meaning, in case a data loss, we can time-travel to a specific time and restore the data.

> Note: Time-travel horizon is limited, and it should be configured manually through the Azure Portal.Portal > Storage Accounts > yourstoraggeaccount > Data Protection > Enable point-in-time restore for containers

You can restore a container using Azure Portal. It is under Storage Accounts > *yourstorageaccount* > Containers.

re a container using Azure Portal. It is under Storage Accounts > *yourstorageaccount* > Containers.

1. Select the container that you want to restore.
2. Click the ‚ÄúRestore Containers > Restore selected‚Äù in the top menu.
3. Enter the date you want to time-travel.
4. (Optional) Enter the specific folders that you want to restore.
5. Click ‚ÄúRestore‚Äù

Please read the following Azure documentation for more details, and to understand the concept well.

- https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/blobs/point-in-time-restore-manage?tabs=portal
- https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/blobs/point-in-time-restore-overview

### Undelete Using Azure Storage Explorer

You can restore a data after deleting it using Azure Storage Explorer by changing the viewing of blob versioning. By default, Azure Storage Explorer shows active blobs of containers.

the viewing of blob versioning. By default, Azure Storage Explorer shows active blobs of containers.

By changing which version we would like to see in container, we can access soft deleted or previous versions any data which has been deleted.

After changing which version we would like to display, user can right-click any data that‚Äôs been deleted and restore it by selecting either simply Undelete or if the user want to go back to a certain version of that data, select Undelete by Date.

In case of restoring by Date, the user must pick the date and time period for which version of the data is wanted to be retrieved as.

user must pick the date and time period for which version of the data is wanted to be retrieved as.

Soft deleted blobs have a retention period which can change depending on lifecycle rules of containers which is managed trough [portal.azure.com](http://portal.azure.com). The retention period is important in case the user wants to recover a soft deleted blob, meaning the data should be recovered within that retention period (say it is 2 days; that means the data will retain in a soft delete version for 2 days and then be completely deleted after).

For more information about blob versions:

- Azure Storage Explorer blob versioning guide

### Undelete Using Azure Python SDK

You can use the following code to undelete deleted blobs:

```py
import datetime
import sys
from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor

from azure.storage.blob import BlobClient, ContainerClient
from dateutil.parser import parse

ecutor

from azure.storage.blob import BlobClient, ContainerClient
from dateutil.parser import parse

ACCOUNT_URL = "https://<storage account name>.blob.core.windows.net"
ACCESS_KEY = "<storage account access key>"
CONTAINER = "<container name>"
# PREFIX = sys.argv[1] # uncomment this if you want to control prefix from cli
# PREFIX = "<blob prefix>"  # uncomment this if you want to set prefix here
TIME_TO_RESTORE = "<time to restore>"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    time_to_restore = parse(TIME_TO_RESTORE)

    container = ContainerClient(account_url=ACCOUNT_URL, container_name=CONTAINER, credential=ACCESS_KEY)
    deleted_blobs = filter(
        lambda d: d["deleted"] and d["deleted_time"] >= time_to_restore,
        container.list_blobs(name_starts_with=PREFIX, include="deleted")
    )

    def undelete(b):
        blob = BlobClient.from_blob_url(
            blob_url=f"{ACCOUNT_URL}/{CONTAINER}/{b['name']}",
            credential=ACCESS_KEY,
        )
        blob.undelete_blob()

/{CONTAINER}/{b['name']}",
            credential=ACCESS_KEY,
        )
        blob.undelete_blob()

    tic = datetime.datetime.now()
    with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=20) as executor:
        _ = executor.map(undelete, deleted_blobs)
    toc = datetime.datetime.now()

    print(toc - tic)
```

To speed up the execution of this code, you can launch an AWS EC2 instance and run the code there.

## Recover Pokedex (DynamoDB)

We save backups on weekly schedule for Pokedex data (on every Sunday at 00:00 UTC).

Backup files can be found in the S3 bucket named ‚Äúinvent-pokedex‚Äù. These files can be used for recovering the system.

## Time Travel in Delta Table

Here you can observe how can you make time travel in delta table: [Time Travel in Delta Table Databricks notebook](https://inventanalytics-apparelgroup2.cloud.databricks.com/?o=4269309644765198#notebook/3046670419434701/command/3046670419434702)

Restore from Glacier.

1. Go to the bucket and select the object you want to restore.Actions - Initiate restore

2. Specify number of days restored files will be available and choose a retrieval tier

/
dbfs:/mnt/invent-alfamart/flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T031034.276Z/

Code

```
#!/bin/bash

bucket="invent-alfamart"
folders=("flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T030534.276Z/"
         "flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T030634.276Z/"
         "flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T030734.276Z/"
         "flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T030834.276Z/"
         "flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T030934.276Z/"
         "flexible_etl_history_test/2024-05-17T031034.276Z/")

for folder in "${folders[@]}"; do
  versions=$(aws s3api list-object-versions --bucket $bucket --prefix $folder)

  echo "$versions" | grep '"IsLatest": false' -B 2 | grep '"Key":' | awk -F'"' '{print $4}' > keys.txt
  echo "$versions" | grep '"IsLatest": false' -B 2 | grep '"VersionId":' | awk -F'"' '{print $4}' > versionIds.txt

ons" | grep '"IsLatest": false' -B 2 | grep '"VersionId":' | awk -F'"' '{print $4}' > versionIds.txt

  paste keys.txt versionIds.txt | while IFS="$(printf '\t')" read -r key version_id; do
    echo "Restoring $key (version: $version_id)"
    aws s3api copy-object --bucket $bucket --copy-source "$bucket/$key?versionId=$version_id" --key $key
  done

  rm keys.txt versionIds.txt
done

```

### Explanation:

1. List Object Versions: List all versions of the objects within the specified folders.
2. Identify Deleted Versions: The script identifies the versions that are not the latest by searching for "IsLatest": false.
3. Extract Keys and Version IDs: It extracts the keys and version IDs of the non-latest versions using grep and awk.
4. Restore Deleted Versions: For each identified version, the script uses the copy-object operation to restore it by copying it back to the same key.

### Running the Script

the copy-object operation to restore it by copying it back to the same key.

### Running the Script

1. Save the script to a file, for example, restore_deleted_folders.sh.
2. Make the script executable:

```
chmod +x restore_deleted_folders.sh
```

1. Run the script:

```
./restore_deleted_folders.sh
```

This will restore the deleted folders and their subfolders to their previous states.

# Bucket name

# Iterate over each object and change storage class to STANDARD

    echo "Checking restore status for: $object_key"

to STANDARD

do
    echo "Checking restore status for: $object_key"

    # Check if object has been restored
    restore_status=$(aws s3api head-object --bucket "$bucket" --key "$object_key" --query "Restore" --output text)

    if [[ "$restore_status" == *"ongoing-request=\"false\""* ]]; then
        echo "Object $object_key is restored. Changing storage class to STANDARD."

        # Change storage class to STANDARD
        aws s3 cp s3://$bucket/$object_key s3://$bucket/$object_key --storage-class STANDARD
    else
        echo "Object $object_key is not yet restored."
    fi
done

echo "Storage class update process completed."

selamlar, invent-boots-wba-datastore/operation/price/ ≈üunu undelete yapmama raƒümen gelmiyor dosyalar, selected by date de yaptƒ±rmƒ±yor, destek olabilir misiniz? d√ºne d√∂necek

Operation (Case)

STORAGE_ACCOUNT="inventboots"

CONTAINER_NAME="invent-boots-wba-datastore"

BLOB_FOLDER="operation/price"

Files: all files under price folder.

```bash
#!/bin/bash

# Variables
STORAGE_ACCOUNT="inventboots"
CONTAINER_NAME="invent-boots-wba-datastore"
BLOB_FOLDER="operation/price"
AZURE_ACCOUNT_KEY="<your_account_key>"

# Optional: Set environment variable for storage account key
# (uncomment this line if using access key authentication)
# export AZURE_STORAGE_KEY=$AZURE_ACCOUNT_KEY

ncomment this line if using access key authentication)
# export AZURE_STORAGE_KEY=$AZURE_ACCOUNT_KEY

# List all blobs in the price folder, including versions
echo "Listing all blobs in the price folder..."
blob_list=$(az storage blob list \
    --account-name $STORAGE_ACCOUNT \
    --container-name $CONTAINER_NAME \
    --prefix "$BLOB_FOLDER" \
    --include v \
    --query "[?properties.blobType=='BlockBlob'].{name: name, versionId: versionId, lastModified: properties.lastModified}" \
    --output tsv)

# Check if any blobs are found
if [ -z "$blob_list" ]; then
    echo "No blobs found in the specified folder."
    exit 1
fi

# Process each blob and restore the latest version
echo "Restoring the latest version of each blob..."
echo "$blob_list" | while read -r line; do
    blob_name=$(echo $line | awk '{print $1}')
    version_id=$(echo $line | awk '{print $2}')

e; do
    blob_name=$(echo $line | awk '{print $1}')
    version_id=$(echo $line | awk '{print $2}')

    # Construct source URI with version ID
    source_uri="https://$STORAGE_ACCOUNT.blob.core.windows.net/$CONTAINER_NAME/$blob_name?versionid=$version_id"

    # Copy the latest version of the blob to itself, making it the current version
    echo "Restoring $blob_name to its latest version (version id: $version_id)..."
    az storage blob copy start \
        --account-name $STORAGE_ACCOUNT \
        --destination-blob "$blob_name" \
        --destination-container "$CONTAINER_NAME" \
        --source-uri "$source_uri" \
        --output none

    echo "$blob_name has been restored to its latest version."
done

echo "All blobs in the $BLOB_FOLDER folder have been restored to their latest versions."

```

### Steps to Use:

obs in the $BLOB_FOLDER folder have been restored to their latest versions."

```

### Steps to Use:

1. Replace <your_account_key> with your actual Azure Storage account key if you're using access key authentication.
2. Make the script executable:chmod +x restore_blob_versions.sh
3. Run the script:./restore_blob_versions.sh

This script should now correctly restore the latest version of each blob to be the current version without running into any errors.

---

## Usage for other operations

1. Replace STORAGE_ACCOUNT with your actual Azure Storage Account (Example: ‚Äúinventboots‚Äù, ‚Äúinventfivebelow‚Äù)
2. Replace CONTAINER_NAME with your actual Azure Storage Blob (Example: ‚Äúinvent-boots-input‚Äù, ‚Äúinvent-fivebelow-output‚Äù)
3. Replace BLOB_FOLDER with your actual Azure Storage Blob Folder (Example: ‚Äúoperation/price‚Äù, ‚Äúanalysis/seasonality_sales_filter‚Äù
4. Replace <your_account_key> with your actual Azure Storage account key if you're using access key authentication.

st practicesImplement recovery models that follow industry best practices for data protection and disaster recovery. This may include setting appropriate backup frequencies, retention periods, and off-site storage.

It's important to think about how to best protect your data before an incident occurs that could compromise it.

### Recommendations for basic data protection

### Lock a storage account

- Configure a lock on the storage account to protect the account from deletion or configuration changesComes with two optionsA CannotDelete lock prevents users from deleting a storage account, but permits reading and modifying its configuration.A ReadOnly lock prevents users from deleting a storage account or modifying its configuration, but permits reading the configuration.No additional cost for lock

Good for ARM or TF

Default Manual Onboards: This feature is not activated

Default Terraform Onboards: This feature is not activated

## Enable container soft delete for the storage account to recover a deleted container and its contents.

nable container soft delete for the storage account to recover a deleted container and its contents.

When container soft delete is enabled for a storage account, a container and its contents may be recovered after it has been deleted, within a retention period that you specify. See [Container Soft Delete](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/blobs/soft-delete-container-enable?tabs=azure-portal)

## Pricing and billing

There's no additional charge to enable container soft delete. Data in soft-deleted containers is billed at the same rate as active data.

# Enable and manage blob versioning

When blob versioning is enabled, then you can restore an earlier version of a blob to recover your data if it is erroneously modified or deleted. See [Blob Versioning](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/blobs/versioning-enable?tabs=portal)

lob Versioning](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/blobs/versioning-enable?tabs=portal)

> Info: After you enable blob versioning for a storage account, every write operation to a blob in that account results in the creation of a new version. For this reason, enabling blob versioning may result in additional costs. To minimize costs, use a lifecycle management policy to automatically delete old versions

# S3 bucket versioning - deletion of delete marker

To backup of files, delete markers should be deleted as script below.

`BUCKET_NAME` = bucket name

`PREFIX` = prefix for files

`{0..131}` = partition list to iterate

`.Hif4f4CRIYBBW27oW1ghJAozuEanffo` = version id to be found on file metadata

`#!/bin/bash
BUCKET_NAME=invent-alfamarttestbulkdata-datastore

sion id to be found on file metadata

`#!/bin/bash
BUCKET_NAME=invent-alfamarttestbulkdata-datastore

for i in {0..131}; do
    PREFIX="rocket_pandas/optimization/run_id=2023-09-30-store_rpl-b3f9f834/partition_id=$i/"
    echo "$PREFIX"
    keys=$(aws s3api list-object-versions --bucket "${BUCKET_NAME}" --prefix "${PREFIX}" --query 'DeleteMarkers[?IsLatest==`true`]'.Key)
    for key in $(echo "${keys}" | jq -r '.[]'); do
        echo "Deleting file: $key"
        aws s3api delete-object --bucket "${BUCKET_NAME}" --key "${key}" --version-id '.Hif4f4CRIYBBW27oW1ghJAozuEanffo' --no-cli-pager
    done
done`

Requirements for recovery:

- Blob versioning is enabled.
- The blob has one or more previous versions.

## Recovery procedures via Azure Portal:

1. Go to the affected blob from the Azure portal.

1. Select the ellipses (...) for the blob you want to recover.
2. Select View versions.

1. Select the version that's required to restore from.
2. Select Make current version.

## Recovery procedures via Azure Storage Explorer:

1. Go to the affected blob from the Storage Explorer.

inventfozzy blobunda invent-fozzy-datastore/dc_rpl/run_input/store_cover_period_forecasts/

1. Filter ‚ÄòActive and soft deleted Blobs‚Äô

run_date=2023-09-03 and run_date=2023-09-04 as soft deleted

1. Choose the blobs you want to recover

Click Undelete Selected.

> Info: Usually Soft delete (Recycle bin) is 4 days as default. After that blob can‚Äôt be reached.

import os

storage_account = "storage account name"

}

container_name = "container name"
dbutils.fs.mount(
    source=f"wasbs://{container_name}@{storage_account}.blob.core.windows.net",
    mount_point=f"/mnt/{container_name}",
    extra_configs=extra_configs,
)

1. Read from the Data Lake Table

This document has been prepared to include information on how to securely store the databases of our customers and Invent applications in accordance with ISO processes and in accordance with data security principles, as well as how databases can be recovered in disaster scenarios that may cause interruptions in applications and servers.

We use databases from different manufacturers depending on the application architecture. The databases we use and manage the most are Microsoft SQL Server and PostgreSQL database systems.

## MSSQL Database Backup and Restore Strategies

metadata.title: Database Backup-Restore and Disaster Recovery Strategies (MSSQL - PostgreSQL)

content:
crosoft SQL Server and PostgreSQL database systems.

## MSSQL Database Backup and Restore Strategies

MS SQL databases run on virtual machines that we install on both AWS and Azure cloud providers. After these installations, we create daily and weekly backup plans within Management Plans via SQL Server Management Studio. As a result of these plans, the database backups are first written to the disks on the server. In a different step within the same job, they are transferred to the storage accounts on the relevant cloud, whichever cloud provider they are on.

> Info: In case of failure to transfer or take backup, job failed information is monitored via alerts.

Our customer MSSQL databases are backed up daily (differential, .diff) and weekly (full, .bak). The backups taken in our daily and weekly maintenance jobs are kept in cloud provider-based S3 or blob storage for a period of 6 months.

AWS S3 Bucket

metadata.title: Database Backup-Restore and Disaster Recovery Strategies (MSSQL - PostgreSQL)

content:
ce jobs are kept in cloud provider-based S3 or blob storage for a period of 6 months.

AWS S3 Bucket

> Info: 1 month of these backups are kept on hot storage and the remaining 5 months are kept on cold storage.

AWS S3 - LCM

Azure Blob Storage

Azure Database Backups LCM Rule

## PostgreSQL Database Backup and Restore Strategies

Our Postgresql databases run on AWS RDS service and Azure Managed services. Under these services, database backups are taken as automated snapshots via maintenance jobs under the conditions recommended by cloud providers. Snapshots are stored for 7 days by default.

### Amazon RDS Backup and Restore

### AWS RDS Backup Operations

Amazon RDS automatically creates a storage volume snapshot of a DB instance, backing up the entire instance. We can restore DB instance to any specific time during the backup retention period, creating a new DB instance.

AWS RDS Postgresql Snapshots

### AWS RDS Restore Operations

metadata.title: Database Backup-Restore and Disaster Recovery Strategies (MSSQL - PostgreSQL)

content:
on period, creating a new DB instance.

AWS RDS Postgresql Snapshots

### AWS RDS Restore Operations

We can restore our DB instance to any specific time during the backup retention period, creating a new DB instance. To restore our postgresql database instance, we can use the AWS Console or Command Line Interface

### Azure Managed Database Service Backup and Restore

### Azure Backup Operations

Backups on Azure Database for PostgreSQL flexible server instances are snapshot based. Transaction log backups happen at varied frequencies, depending on the workload and when the WAL file is filled and ready to be archived. In general, the delay (recovery point objective, or RPO) can be up to 5 minutes.

metadata.title: Database Backup-Restore and Disaster Recovery Strategies (MSSQL - PostgreSQL)

content:
ady to be archived. In general, the delay (recovery point objective, or RPO) can be up to 5 minutes.

Backup type is Zone-redundant and this option provides us to backup data availability across availability zones and restricts replication of data to within a country/region to meet data residency requirements. This option provides at least 99.9999999999 percent (12 nines) durability of backup objects over a year.

> Info: Azure Database for PostgreSQL flexible server automatically creates server backups and stores them in Zone-redundant storage, in regions where multiple zones are supported

If the backups are stored in geo-redundant backup storage, in addition to three copies of data stored within the region where our server is hosted which is West Europe, the data is replicated to a geo-paired region that is North Europe.

> Info: Regions might be varied for customer based location. Therefore, zone might be changed according to situation

### Azure Restore Operations

metadata.title: Database Backup-Restore and Disaster Recovery Strategies (MSSQL - PostgreSQL)

content:
ased location. Therefore, zone might be changed according to situation

### Azure Restore Operations

Since our postgresql source server is configured with a private access virtual network, we can restore either to the same virtual network or to a different virtual network.

Azure supports PITR for all servers. We can restore to the latest restore point or a custom restore point by using the Azure portal, the Azure CLI, and the API

In Geo-Redundant option restore allows us to restore our server to paired region in the event of a disaster or we can restore to the latest restore point or a custom restore point by using the Azure portal. The physical database files are first restored from the snapshot backups to the server's data location. The appropriate backup that was taken earlier than the desired point in time is automatically chosen and restored. A recovery process then starts by using WAL files to bring the database to a consistent state.

content:
Please restore every files under this path:

bucket="invent-alfamartblue-datastore"
prefix="noob/forecast-coefficients/historic/coeffs/run_date=2024-09-01/"

```
#!/bin/bash
set -euo pipefail

# Bucket and prefix
bucket="invent-alfamartblue-datastore"
prefix="noob/forecast-coefficients/historic/coeffs/run_date=2024-09-01/"

echo "Listing objects under s3://$bucket/$prefix ..."

# Get all object keys under the prefix
# AWS CLI auto-paginates, so 401 objects is fine.
mapfile -t objects < <(
  aws s3api list-objects-v2 \
    --bucket "$bucket" \
    --prefix "$prefix" \
    --query 'Contents[].Key' \
    --output text
)

if [ ${#objects[@]} -eq 0 ]; then
  echo "No objects found under prefix: $prefix"
  exit 1
fi

echo "Found ${#objects[@]} objects. Starting Glacier restores..."

# Iterate over each object and restore from Glacier
count=0
for object_key in "${objects[@]}"; do
  count=$((count + 1))
  echo "[$count/${#objects[@]}] Initiating restore for: s3://$bucket/$object_key"

unt=$((count + 1))
  echo "[$count/${#objects[@]}] Initiating restore for: s3://$bucket/$object_key"

  # Initiate restore request (change Tier or Days if you want)
  aws s3api restore-object \
    --bucket "$bucket" \
    --key "$object_key" \
    --restore-request '{
      "Days": 7,
      "GlacierJobParameters": { "Tier": "Expedited" }
    }' \
  || echo "  -> restore failed or already in progress for: $object_key"
done

echo "Restore requests initiated for all objects under $prefix."

```

1. chmod +x restore.sh
2. ./restore.sh

For running lower Bash 4 version (mapfile: command not found), alternatively you can use

```bash
#!/bin/bash
set -euo pipefail

bucket="invent-alfamartblue-datastore"
prefix="noob/forecast-coefficients/historic/coeffs/run_date=2024-09-01/"

echo "Listing objects under s3://$bucket/$prefix ..."

icients/historic/coeffs/run_date=2024-09-01/"

echo "Listing objects under s3://$bucket/$prefix ..."

# List objects and loop over each key
aws s3api list-objects-v2 \
  --bucket "$bucket" \
  --prefix "$prefix" \
  --query 'Contents[].Key' \
  --output text | tr '\t' '\n' | while read -r object_key; do

    # Skip empty lines
    if [[ -z "$object_key" ]]; then
        continue
    fi

    echo "Initiating restore for: $object_key"

    aws s3api restore-object \
      --bucket "$bucket" \
      --key "$object_key" \
      --restore-request '{
        "Days": 7,
        "GlacierJobParameters": { "Tier": "Expedited" }
      }' || echo "  -> Failed or already restoring: $object_key"

done

echo "All restore requests initiated."

```

1. chmod +x restore.sh
2. ./restore.sh
